Award.AwardTitle: Mentoring, Academic Support and Scholarships for Science Students (MAS4)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Grand Valley State University Mentoring, Academic Support, and Scholarships for Science Students program supports academically talented, innovative, and creative students with demonstrated financial need. The program recruits transfer students from nearby Grand Rapids Community College. Scholarship students are selected based on a personal statement, letters of recommendation, a plan of study, and academic accomplishments. The program provides 30 scholarships per year. The disciplines supported are: biology, cell & molecular biology, chemistry, computer science, engineering, geology, integrated science, information systems, mathematics, physics, and statistics. Students selected to participate in this program progress through the program as a cohort, both as a collective group and as smaller discipline-specific groups. Each student is matched with a faculty mentor who is an advocate throughout his or her academic career. Scholars are supported from admission through graduation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Synthesis of outcomes

The overall goal of the S-STEM Mentoring, Academic Support, and Scholarships for Science Students (MAS4) project was to help STEM majors surmount challenges on their way to graduation. The project provided scholarships and academic support to STEM students who are Pell eligible and meet the criteria outlined by NSF. An implicit goal of the project was to increase the retention and graduation rates of this population of students at Grand Valley State University (GVSU). An additional focus of the MAS4 grant was recruiting and supporting transfer students from nearby Grand Rapids Community College (GRCC).

Each academic year of the MAS4 project, starting in 2011-12, we identified eligible students during their sophomore year, and awarded between 25-44 scholarships, with average awards between $2,197 and $5,988, annually, for five years. Of these, ten scholarships were awarded to students transferring from GRCC. The overall graduation/retention rate among the S-STEM MAS4 awardees was 97.9%, which compares favorably to the average rate at GVSU and other Pell-eligible institutions.

The financial support from the scholarship had several positive effects for S-STEM MAS4 awardees, in terms of the time they had available to focus on challenging course work and remaining in their programs. A key outcome of the project was its contribution to an increase in the number and quality of STEM students moving to graduate school. Another key project outcome was connecting S-STEM students with other resources and leveraging university and external resources, while increasing the direct financial support available to the students. The project had positive impacts on institutional resources that form infrastructure. For example, the success of an S-STEM student as one of the first AutoCam Scholars helped establish this effort as a continuing scholarship program that will benefit six students each year with 50% tuition scholarships and guaranteed paid co-op work experience. The success of this program has also led to another company establishing a similar scholarship for three students per year with full tuition support and guaranteed paid co-op work experience. Both of these programs serve the same student population as the S-STEM program. The combination of these two programs now provides work experience and financial support for nine students totaling over $80,000 in scholarships and over $45,000 in co-op earnings each year.

In addition to the financial support, S-STEM MAS4 awardees benefited from additional academic support in the form of assigned faculty mentors, travel support for professional development and conference attendance, and support from advising, tutoring, and career services. During the grant period, ten awardees engaged in research with mentors, and ten awardees received travel support and presented at conferences. The project also had impacts on the mentors via personal and professional growth. They were energized by working with this group of highly motivated students and expanded research activity and publications via working with the S-STEM students.

The S-STEM MAS4 grant activities increased the pipeline of students retained in STEM disciplines and advancing forward towards STEM careers. The grant activities contributed to workforce development in the region, which has impacts from the perspectives of social justice and the local economy.
